Comment: Here is a gamelet from a real-time rapidplay tournament I played in last week. My opponent and I were both on 4/4 so far - in this game someone's 100% score was going to end. The fact that my opponent was the top seed, with an ECF grade 49 points higher than mine, didn't help my optimism.
I play my principal opening as Black, the French Defence.
Main line. White occupies the centre with a Classical Pawn Centre.
Black's most usual response, challenging White's powerful-looking centre.
The Advance Variation of the French Defence.

An important move for Black: striking at the d-pawn. Black's overall aim in the Advance French is to target White's advanced central pawns, particularly the d-pawn, in an attempt to bring the d-pawn and then the undefended e-pawn down. 3...c5 is a good way of starting this.
White tries to solidify his advanced pawns.
Building up the pressure on White's central pawns.

Before this move, I was planning Nge7 followed by Nf5 to bring up another attack on the d-pawn. However, now my inexperience really shows. Surely, I thought at this moment, this move blocks White's queen's defence of the d-pawn and loses that pawn! This would enable me to very quickly bring down White's over-extended central pawns, and win one into the bargain! I felt immense euphoria at being the beneficiary of such an error by a person rated 49 points above me.

However, I see you more experienced players looking on this position and shaking your heads with a knowing smile. You know what I have missed...as did I a few moves later.

Snap snap snap. I have won a pawn! My opponent, younger than me, was looking at this position with a supreme poker-face. This was when the cold claw of fear gripped my heart. Maybe, just maybe, the top seed had noticed something I hadn't?

Snap snap snap. I have won a pawn! My opponent, younger than me, was looking at this position with a supreme poker-face. This was when the cold claw of fear gripped my heart. Maybe, just maybe, the top seed had noticed something I hadn't?

Snap snap snap. I have won a pawn! My opponent, younger than me, was looking at this position with a supreme poker-face. This was when the cold claw of fear gripped my heart. Maybe, just maybe, the top seed had noticed something I hadn't?

With this eye-popping move, my opponent expressionlessly wins my queen. I didn't want to continue this game any more. I resigned on the spot. I could feel my face going through an interesting selection of pastel colours, as I gazed upon what is without a doubt the most embarassing moment of my chess career. Go on, readers, feel free to call me a complete idiot! The more comments you post the less likely it is that I will fall into this trap again!
